title: News regarding MediaGroup
story_body:
MediaGroup Announces Marketing Leadership Change, Plans Industry Conference Participation

MediaGroup Inc. (NASDAQ: MEDIA) announced today that Jennifer Chen has been promoted to Senior Vice President of Digital Marketing, effective immediately. Chen, who previously served as Vice President of Marketing Strategy, will oversee the company's digital marketing initiatives and report directly to Chief Marketing Officer David Martinez.

"Jennifer has been instrumental in developing our digital presence over the past five years," Martinez said in a statement. "Her promotion reflects her contributions to our marketing efforts and positions us well for continued growth in digital channels."

Chen joined MediaGroup in 2019 and has led several successful campaigns for the company's streaming and content divisions. She holds an MBA from Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.

The company also announced that several executives, including CEO Robert Thompson and Chief Technology Officer Sarah Williams, will attend the upcoming Digital Media Summit in Las Vegas next month. The three-day conference, scheduled for March 15-17, brings together media industry leaders to discuss emerging trends and technologies.

MediaGroup plans to host a panel discussion on content monetization strategies during the conference. The company will also maintain a booth in the exhibition hall to showcase its latest advertising technology platform.

In addition, MediaGroup revealed details of its spring marketing campaign, "Connect More," which aims to highlight the company's streaming service features. The multi-channel campaign will include television commercials, digital advertisements, and social media content across major platforms. The campaign is set to launch in early April and run through June.

As part of its environmental initiatives, MediaGroup announced it will transition to renewable energy sources for two additional data centers by the end of 2024. The company currently operates 12 data centers across North America, with four already powered by renewable energy.

"We're committed to reducing our carbon footprint while maintaining the reliability our customers expect," said Lisa Park, MediaGroup's Director of Sustainability. The data center transitions are expected to reduce the company's carbon emissions by approximately 8% annually once completed.

MediaGroup shares closed at $47.32 on Tuesday, down 0.3% for the day. The stock has gained 12% year-to-date.
